snippet: An analysis by two consultancies, the Edge and Deloitte, found that such corporate breakups add, on average, 14 percent to a parent company’s stock price by a year after the move, while the spun-off entity enjoys a 22 percent rise in its own...
abstract: An analysis by two consultancies, the Edge and Deloitte, found that such corporate breakups add, on average, 14 percent to a parent company’s stock price by a year after the move, while the spun-off entity enjoys a 22 percent rise in its own shares.

byline.original: By MICHAEL J. DE LA MERCED

headline.main: Corporate Spinoffs Expected to Grow Next Year, Study Finds
